paragraphs.text:
%md
## Spark notebook
This Spark notebook is written in Scala which is a JVM language. It is also possible to write Spark notebooks in Python and R but this is not covered in this Lab. The first time a paragraph is executed it will request resources from the cluster (using YARN) which takes some time. Subsequent paragraphs will be faster as resources have been registered.

msg.data:
Spark notebook

This Spark notebook is written in Scala which is a JVM language. It is also possible to write Spark notebooks in Python and R but this is not covered in this Lab. The first time a paragraph is executed it will request resources from the cluster (using YARN) which takes some time. Subsequent paragraphs will be faster as resources have been registered.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Data loading
Some data need to be loaded to get started. Spark supports many data sources and formats like files (JSON, XML, CSV, etc.) and databases (relational and NoSQL). Data is read into a Dataframe object which is a data structure what represents a stronly typed table. Hence Dataframes have a schema (with optionally nested fields) and supports typical SQL operations like select, where and filter.

msg.data:
Data loading

Some data need to be loaded to get started. Spark supports many data sources and formats like files (JSON, XML, CSV, etc.) and databases (relational and NoSQL). Data is read into a Dataframe object which is a data structure what represents a stronly typed table. Hence Dataframes have a schema (with optionally nested fields) and supports typical SQL operations like select, where and filter.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
// The next paragraph loads the JSON data from MapR-DB JSON as  created by the image classification service. Each record contains information on objects that have been recognized within an uploaded image. The JSON is parsed by Spark and put in a dataframe object. You get some insight into the data by printing the schema, record count and some example records 
import com.mapr.db.spark._
import com.mapr.db.spark.sql._

val image_tags = spark.loadFromMapRDB("/image-classification/output/database/image-output-table")
println("Total number of records: "+image_tags.count())
println("--- [ SCHEMA ] ---")
image_tags.printSchema()

%spark
// print the top 10 recods using the dataframe (creates ascii art table that is not always readable...) 
println("--- [ EXAMPLE TABLE (10 records) ] ---")
image_tags.show(10)

// print 1 recod using the RDD (the datastructure that sits under the hood of the databrame) which contains all information. This will show that a single image can contain many recognized objects.
println("--- [ ONLY FIRST RECORD ] ---")
image_tags.rdd.take(1).foreach(println)

%md
### Transformations
After loading and checking the data it is common to transform it into something usable. This typically means selecting specific fields, removing rows (filter), transforming fields (using UDF's) or aggregating the data. The following paragraphs show some of these functions.

msg.data:
Transformations

After loading and checking the data it is common to transform it into something usable. This typically means selecting specific fields, removing rows (filter), transforming fields (using UDF’s) or aggregating the data. The following paragraphs show some of these functions.

paragraphs.text:
%spark
// The nested 'object' array is a bit inconvenient so lets 'explode' the objects array such that each recognized object will have its own record. This will increase the number of records
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.explode

val image_tags_expl = image_tags.withColumn("object", explode($"objects")).drop("objects")
println("Total number of records: "+ image_tags_expl.count )
image_tags_expl.printSchema()

%md
### SQL Interpreter
Once a table has been registered in memory it is possible to query it using the %sql interpreter. This interpreter has some visualisation options like bar, pie and line charts.

msg.data:
SQL Interpreter

Once a table has been registered in memory it is possible to query it using the %sql interpreter. This interpreter has some visualisation options like bar, pie and line charts.

paragraphs.text:
%sql
-- This is the same aggregation as executed before. Feel free to replace this with other queries you can think of and execute these
SELECT object.label, avg(object.confidence) AS avg_confidence, count(1) as cnt, avg(surface) AS avg_surface
    FROM image_tags
    GROUP BY object.label
    ORDER BY avg_confidence DESC
    LIMIT 100

%md
### Spark ML
Spark has an extensive machine learning library which contains statistical methods as wel as ML algorithms. The following paragraphs use the Statistics library to calculate any correlation between object surface and image classification confidence.

msg.data:
Spark ML

Spark has an extensive machine learning library which contains statistical methods as wel as ML algorithms. The following paragraphs use the Statistics library to calculate any correlation between object surface and image classification confidence.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### That is it folks!
Feel free to copy paragraphs from above and experiment with them. For example execute other SQL queries or try to find the correlation between the location of the object and recognition confidcence. I am sure you can think of other cools things to do :)
